entry.title: 'Penguin' etymology - external edit
entry.summary:
'Penguin' etymology
The origin of the English word 'Penguin' is obscure.
It's been suggested that it may have come from the Welsh words pen - meaning 'head' - and gwyn - meaning 'white'.
Though, notably, many penguins don't have white heads, and are scarce in Wales.

entry.title: Radiotrophic Fungi - ↷ Page moved from content:life_sciences:botany:radiotrophic_fungi to content:life_sciences:fungi:radiotrophic_fungi
entry.summary:
Radiotrophic Fungi
Radiotrophic fungi were first discovered in 2000 as black moulds growing inside and around the damaged Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine. Subsequent research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine showed that three melanin-containing fungi,

entry.title: Electrical activity in fungi - ↷ Page moved from content:life_sciences:botany:fungal_electrical_signals to content:life_sciences:fungi:fungal_electrical_signals
entry.summary:
Electrical activity in fungi
It's been established that many species of fungi generate small electric potentials (c. 100 mV) in their webs of underground fibres.
It's unknown what significance these electrical potentials may or may not have. Some research groups have suggested that they could form the basis of 'signals' between fungi - or even between the fungi and nearby plants.

entry.title: Travelling Salesman Problem - ↷ Page name changed from content:computer_science:the_ravelling_salesman_problem to content:computer_science:the_travelling_salesman_problem
entry.summary:
Travelling Salesman Problem
The Travelling Salesman (TSP) is a problem of Theoretical Computer Science and Graph Optimization.
"Given a list of cities and the distances between each pair of cities, what is the shortest possible route that visits each city just once and returns to the origin city?"

entry.title: The Liar Paradox
entry.summary:
The Liar Paradox
The Liar Paradox is a logic problem that goes back (at least) as far as the Ancient Greeks.
Example :
A known liar, who never tells the truth, says "I am lying". If he is, as usual, lying, then his statement is false - meaning that he's telling the truth. Leading to a seemingly unsolvable paradoxical situation.

entry.title: Boreal forest rings
entry.summary:
Boreal forest rings
Forest rings are persistent, large-scale unusual growth ´rings´ (circular or oval) which can form in boreal forests. They are typically 50m - 2,000m across. The edge borders of the rings tend to feature a depression about 3m deep, and can be 10-30m in width.

entry.title: Spontaneous remission (cancer)
entry.summary:
Spontaneous remission (cancer)
Spontaneous remission (a.k.a. spontaneous recession and spontaneous regression ) refers to the rare but very well documented phenomenon of recovery from medically diagnosed cancers of various types.* See note
"The rare but spectacular phenomenon of spontaneous remission of cancer persists in the annals of medicine, totally inexplicable but real, a hypothetical straw to clutch in the search for cure. From time to time patients turn up with far advanced cancer, be…
